title: How to Perform a Ping Check with Grafana Cloud Synthetic Monitoring

blocks.content:
# How to Perform a Ping Check with Grafana Cloud Synthetic Monitoring

In this interactive guide you'll learn how to set up and run a ping check in Grafana Cloud Synthetic Monitoring. You will:

- Understand what a ping check is and when to use it
- Create and configure a ping check for any endpoint
- Select probe locations for global monitoring coverage
- Set up alerting so you're notified when your endpoint goes down

### **Why Use Ping Checks?**

- **Verify reachability** â€“ Confirm that an endpoint is online and responding to ICMP packets
- **Measure latency** â€“ Track round-trip response time from probe locations around the world
- **Detect downtime proactively** â€“ Get alerted before your users notice an outage

## Section 1: Navigate to Synthetic Monitoring

Let's start by navigating to the Testing & Synthetics section in Grafana Cloud. This is where you create and manage all your synthetic checks.
In the main menu, navigate to **Testing & Synthetics**.
Click **Synthetic Monitoring** to open the Synthetics home page.
Click **Create new check** to get started.
Select **API Endpoint** as the check type. Ping, HTTP, DNS, TCP, and Traceroute checks are all found here.

## Section 2: Configure the Ping Check

Now let's configure the ping check. You'll give it a name, set the request type to Ping, and specify the target endpoint you want to monitor.
Enter a **Job Name** for your check, for example **MyApp:Ping**.

blocks.reftarget: label[title='Check a host for availability and response time.']
blocks.content: Set the **Request Type** to **Ping**.
Enter your **Request Target** â€” the hostname or IP address to ping, for example **grafana.com**.

## Section 3: Optional Parameters

In this section you can review optional uptime and label settings for your ping check. These can be left as defaults for a basic setup.
Click **Uptime** to move to the next configuration section.
Optionally adjust the **Timeout** value if required.
Move to the **Labels** section.
Optionally add **Labels** to help organize your checks.

## Section 4: Select Probe Locations

Probes are monitoring agents located around the globe that send ICMP echo packets to your target. Selecting multiple locations gives you a global view of your endpoint's availability and latency.
Click **Execution** to move to the probe configuration section.
Select one or more **Probe Locations** to run the ping check from.
Optionally adjust the **Probe Frequency**. The default of 1 minute is suitable for most checks.

## Section 5: Configure Alerting

Alerting ensures you're notified as soon as your endpoint becomes unreachable. Set a failure threshold that makes sense for your service's tolerance for downtime.
Click **Alerting** to move to the alerting configuration section.
Enable the **Probe Failed Executions** alert by clicking the checkbox.
Optionally click **Test** to validate the ping check before saving.
Click **Save** to create your ping check. Grafana Cloud will begin executing it immediately.

## ðŸŽ‰ Congratulations!

You've successfully set up a ping check in Grafana Cloud Synthetic Monitoring. You can now:

- View results in the out-of-the-box **Synthetic Monitoring dashboard**, which shows uptime, reachability, and average latency
- Monitor **response latency by probe location** to understand your endpoint's global performance
- Receive **alerts** the moment your endpoint becomes unreachable

To learn more, explore other check types such as HTTP, DNS, and TCP checks â€” or set up private probes to monitor internal services not accessible from the public internet.
